results.notes:
“And the unthinkable happened again”; I’ll try to explain:
I went to this place to revisit the lichen considered in observation 224457; Encountered it again and took new photos for my records.
Then I saw a piece of brick lying on the soil covered with apothecia, resembling those of the lichen that I finished to observe. At home, analyzing the photos there was no doubt, the apothecia were “equal” and the microscopy gave the same results than expected and that should be compared with those in observation 224457.
How is this possible? In the lichen of observation 224457 the thallus is like a piece of chalk from which the apothecia emerge, being spread by the thallus. In this piece of brick the thallus is inconspicous and the apothecia are crowded. It is very difficult to digest these peculiarities …

Habitat: pasture, at the edge of the mixed forest, Fagus sylvatica, Ostrya carpinifolia and Picea abies dominant trees; moderately inclined slope at the foot of mountains, south east aspect; colluvial, skeletal, calcareous ground; mostly sunny place; relatively warm and dry place; exposed to direct rain, average precipitation ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 615 m (2.020 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: dead, thick, partly decorticated branch of Ostrya carpinifolia laying on ground; fund on top side of it; wood still firm, hard to cut; in its initial state of disintegration.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča; pasture west of Strgulc abandoned farm house, Soča 47, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Three aethaila found in a circle of about 0.4 m diameter. This myxomicete can be recognized by its vividly pink (not yet mature) aethalia, white hypothallus, characteristic spores, which are distinctly reticulate only on about 2/3 of their surface and persistent pseudocapillitium consisting of membranous perforated plates and threads. Reticularia splendens var. jurana can be distinguished from Reticularia splendens var. splendens by smaller size of aethalia and flaccid cortex.

To my knowledge this is the second or third find of this species in Slovenia and the first one in the Julian Alps.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

Colors as seen in photos are accurate. Surface of stipe base difficult to read; buried in soil. Rest of stipe surface minutely punctate.

Context in lower 30% of stipe red upon sectioning, slowly overtaken by dark blue stain. Rest of context immediately dark blue upon sectioning, except for some spotty pale areas.

Ammonia (applied 12 hours after collected): mahogany to blackish on cap, rusty orange fading to yellowish near the perimeter on cap context, muddy brownish orange with lighter perimeter on blues stipe context.
KOH (applied 12 hours after collected): mahogany to blackish on cap surface, rusty orange on cap context, brown on blued stipe context, muddy orange on context in stipe base.

Occurs on soil deposits in nooks and crannies on an intruded siliceous rock outcrop in a semi-arid grassland setting.

Thallus squamulose; squamules flat, adnate, reddish brown, without soredia or isidia, with indistinct lower cortex, lacking rhizines but with thick attachment of rhizohyphae. Medulla composed of roundish to angular cells. Ascomata are immersed perethecia without algae in the cavity. Perethecia with pale walls, becoming brown in age, hymenium hyaline.

Asci with 8 spores. Spores uniserate, hyaline, simple, ellipsoid.
Measurements (ave): 13.7×5.9 (n=5)

Originally posted as part of the mixed collection obs 257753.
Collected for RET and will be shipped to him soon.

results.notes:
A COMA Foray collection. Unfortunately I failed to record where this remarkably fresh and juicy collection had originated from, but this gorgeous bolete must have come from one of the sites visited that day by the COMA folks: Round Ball Mountain or Rheinstrom Hill Audubon Sanctuary or Appalachian Trail near Sheffield-Egremont Rd. or Mt. Washington State Forest or Mt. Everett High School.
Having never seen this taxon before, I was scratching my head for a while. Luckily, Bill and Robert came to my rescue – this was what they had been calling Lanmaoa carminipes in Connecticut. The name certainly doesn’t help with identification, as there are only traces of red color in the stipe. Go figure! The bluing of the flesh is remarkable in its onset and intensity – eat your heart out, B. subvelutipes and C. pulverulentus! :-)
DNA Results and Discussion (posted on 31-Mar-19):
Results:
> A 1558 bps nrDNA sequence has been obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. It consists of the last 579 bps of nrITS and the first 979 bps of nrLSU (through to and including the LR5 primer).
> The ITS sequence is a single reverse read, a bonus from Linas. It features complete 5.8S and ITS2 subloci of 161 and 277 bps, respectively, and an incomplete ITS1 region of 141 bps. There are a total of 15 ambiguous bases in this sequence, some of which would probably get resolved with a forward read. In particular, there is a large region of heterogeneity in the beginning of ITS2 that accounts for the lion’s share of ambiguities (9) — SMWKGSYTKGRAW. The remaining 6 ambiguities are isolated SNP events (4 x “Y” and 2 x “R”) scattered about the sequence.
A BLASTn of this sequence gave the following 3 top hits:
1) KY826163 = Boletales sp. voucher RL008; 564/579 = 97.4% similar (the 15 mismatches are the ambiguities in MO258950)
2) KM248928 = Boletus sp. JAB-2014 isolate 3733; 564/579 = 97.4% similar (the 15 mismatches are the ambiguities in MO258950)
3) KY826054 = Boletales sp. voucher B1751; 520/540 = 96.3% similar (13 ambiguities in MO258950, 5 ambiguities in KY826054, 1 gap in poly “G”, and 1 C/T mismatch)
The three GenBank accessions are associated with Canadian vouchers. Looking at the sequences, there is no doubt in my mind that they are conspecific with each other and with MO258950. Other than these 3 accessions, there is nothing else close in GenBank — the 4 th hit is only 91% similar.
Since one of the relevant hits is Renée Lebeuf’s collection (KY826163), I contacted her regarding the possible identification of her voucher RL008. Renée’s response was: “RL008 corresponds to my HRL1159 and matches with what we call here Boletus sensibilior nom. prov. Lamoureux”. With Renée’s permission, I’ve uploaded 3 pictures of RL008/HRL1159. Despite the somewhat variable appearance, it’s undoubtedly the same species/organism, as the photographs were taken within minutes of each other. Note the varying degree and intensity of the red color in the stipe.
> The LSU sequence is a clean and contiguous consensus sequence of two reads. There are 3 ambiguous characters, all are “Y” (C/T).
A BLASTn of a 857 bps sequence fragment (the region between the ITS6R and LR5 primers) gave a sole hit of >99% similarity — KF030310 associated with Ernst Both’s “Boletus sensibilis var. subviscidus voucher 3929”. Other than the 2 ambiguities in MO258950, there are 4 mismatching positions in the GB sequence represented by gaps; however, they appear in the beginning of the sequence, so in all likelihood they are the result of poor editing. For all practical purposes, I believe the two sequences are identical.
Looking at the other BLASTn hits below and seeing lots of Neoboletus, as well as taxa from an assortment of other “orphan” clades in the “Pulveroboletus Group” of Wu et al. (2014, 2016), where Lanmaoa itself belongs at this time, I decided to build a GB-based tree to see where this COMA critter actually fits. The annotated phylogram is uploaded to this observation.
There are two main features in this cladogram that are a puzzle: first, the monophily of Lanmaoa cannot be maintained, as it’s consistently split into two clades labeled as 2A and 2B; second, MO258950 is not a member of either Lanmaoa clade and instead nests in Neoboletus! While the first puzzle can be attributed to LSU itself and/or GenBank’s statistical software, the second one is more difficult to explain, especially in light of the morphology of MO258950 being consistent with Lanmaoa.
Discussion:
Unfortunately, sequencing with ITS and LSU did neither shed sufficient light onto the identity of this collection, nor did it firmly place this ostensibly looking Lanmaoa taxon into that genus. While very similar/essentially identical GenBank accessions were found for both tested loci, ITS gave a match to a provisional unpublished name (B. sensibilior) and the sole LSU hit was associated with a questionably identified voucher of an obscure variety of B. sensibilis.
As to the identity of Smith & Thiers’ L. carminipes, it will continue to be a mystery till the holotype collection is sequenced. Looking at the description of this taxon in The Boletes of Michigan, the salient morphological features are the colors of the cap and stipe and the intense bluing, but IMO this gestalt is similar to that of L. pseudosensibilis, also described by the two gents on the adjacent page of TBofMI. In particular, the cap color of pseudosensibilis is quite variable. Indeed, as per the posted LSU cladogram, Ernst Both’s collection of carminipes (KF030259) is closely related to my vouchers identified as pseudosensibilis. The dried holotype of carminipes can be visualized here:
http://storage.idigbio.org/...
I’ve asked Dr. Kudzma to sample this collection for TEF-1. The goal here is to be able to place this species into a genus more confidently.

results.notes: Initially identified as A. ocreata, except there are no oak and it not within the season. A white variety of A. calyptroderma is implied in Lincoff’s description growing around Dour fir and Madrone, precisely these woods. Smooth white cap 3" dia. almost entirely covered by a white patch. No radial lines at the margin however. White spore print and other features as per Lincoff. eg. of the two growing together, the larger had lost its pendant ring but the smaller one still had it hanging. Little odor. No way I’m going to eat this, sorry. If I’m correct, it is a white Coccora.

results.notes:
Pileus: +/- 25 × 35 mm; ovoid, later campanulate, eventually expanded and with revolute margin; smooth, weakly sulcate at first, becoming more sulcate with age; grey with slightly browner centre; entirely covered with white to in the centre slightly browner, fairly thick squamose-fibrillose velum.

Lamellae: Numerous, free to narrowly adnexed, narrow; brown with paler, greyish margin, later black; deliquescent.

Stipe: Up to 110 × 5 mm; central, cilindrical, slightly tapering towards the pileus, somewhat clavate, sometimes flexuous; entirely and densely floccose-fibrillose with ever so slightly smoother foot with minute annulate zone (not unlike a sock).

Context: Fairly thin at first, later fragile; whitish in cortex, brownish grey innercortex, darker in pileus and foot; very soon hollow in stipe.

Smell/taste: Faint earthy smell, no taste recorded.

Microscopy:
- Spores: 6,12-7,14 × 5,10-6,12 micron, broadly ellipsoid to ovoid (initially described as subglobose with acute apex); truncate; brown, hyaline.
- Velum: chains of large sausage-shaped inflated cells, hyaline.

Ecology: solitary or subcespitose on bare, eutrophic, disturbed soil, possibly on burried, dead or decaying plant matter.

Lamellae: Numerous, crowded, narrow, barely touching stipe; smooth margin; pale brown to reddish brown, eventually black; deliquescent.

I only ended up bringing home small bits of this lichen so I will definitely have to go back for a real specimen. I believe this is the same taxon as reported in observation 251055, but as you can see in that observation the ID is not confirmed.

Thallus red-brown, K-, C-, KC- (at least that I could tell, should be pink for P. badia, but with the red-brown cortex color I couldn’t see any color change even at 100x), and also it appears to be UV- (should be UV+white for P. badia). Apothecia superficial, lecanorine, disk reddish brown to dark brown, algal layer thick across base of apothecia, sometimes discontinuous. Photobiont green algae. Paraphyses observed were unbranched. Epihymenium cinnamon or reddish brown with a clear epinecral layer, hymenium hyaline to dingy, K/I+Blue (asci only?), fading, hypothecium hyaline, composed of hyphal strands, not cellular.

Spores appeared to be 8/ascus, although it was hard to tell, the asci seemed very small for the spores I was finding ejected. Spores simple, hyaline, narrowly ellipsoid, slightly narrowing on one end in some but not all spores.

results.notes:
This is a very tiny “pimple” without a visible thallus and consisting of single black apothecia about 0.1mm in diameter. They are mostly situated in small depressions of the rock, which I believe is a shale, maybe calcareous. I couldn’t get photos of the apothecia, but just imagine tiny black dots widely spaced.

I will say that I may have two things going on in this observation, the original target lichen and a lichenicolous fungi. I’m really not sure, but what I am after is the ID of the target lichen which seems like Catillaria or something but I can’t get a match to the distinctive spores.

Spores are 1-septate with lower chamber larger, globose.
18.0×7.8µm, 18.9×7.1µm.

I went to far dark corners of various Caloplaca keys with this one, fooled by the seemingly brown thallus, which is in reality orange but is covered by particles from the rock making it the same color as the rock. But the real question is, what is the sterile black Verrucaria like thing?

Thallus orange, with abundant orange apothecia initials, all parts K+R. Medulla layer is very small. Apothecia are small, about 0.5mm, dull orange, pruinose, with raised margin lacking algae (proper margin dominant) and thick algal layer across base. Exciple and layer below hypothecium not paraplectenchymatous. Hymenium hyaline, epihymenium golden brown, K+R.

Spores 8 per ascus, ellipsoid, hyaline, polarilocular. 11.7×6.6, 9.9×6.7, 10.1×5.5µm, with isthmus 2.1-3.4µm after heat treatment.

locally with hardly visible veins or nearly smooth, particularly closer to or on the
stipe apex and near the cap margin, young sometimes a very pale pink, at maturity
a beautiful salmon orange.” (as per Bart Buyck)

From the paper by Bart Buyck et al, Cantharellus coccolobae sp. nov.
and Cantharellus garnieri, two tropical members
of Cantharellus subg. Cinnabarinus published in Cryptogamie, Mycologie, 2016, 37 (3): 391-403

results.notes:
Description:

Pileus: 19-30 mm; campanulate to convex, later with uplifted to revolute margin; smooth cuticle, sulcate with smooth centre; covered with floccose-filamentose velum, white of colour; dark grey with paler margin and darker reddish brown centre; hygrophanous.

Lamellae: Not very crowded when expanded, free, very narrow; grey at first, later black; entirely deliquescent.

Stipe: 38-58 × 1,5-2 mm; central, cilindrical, slightly tapering towards the pileus; longitudinally striate, densely covered with fibrillose squamules, denser towards the base, there with very dense fibrils and slight fibrillose annular zone; entirely white.

Context: Very thin; white, brownish in the foot and the centre of the pileus; hollow in the stipe.

Smell/Taste: Smells earthy; no taste recorded.

Microscopy:

- Spores: Amygdaliform, warty, excentric apiculus, central germpore; reddish brown, hyaline.

- Measurements (1000x, oil-immersion, H2O, 1 sd=1,02 micron):
8,16-9,18 × 5,10-6,12 micron.

Ecology: On small piece of burried broadleaf wood on very eutrophic, disturbed soil.

Notes: Changed from C. echinospora to C. phlyctidospora based on smaller, more rounded spores and smaller germpore.
results.location_name: Aarschot, Vlaanderen, Belgium

results.notes:
Description:

Pileus: 58×11 mm; convex, a bit irregular, with little crenate-sulcate margin; dry and smooth surface; slightly depressed centre; vinaceous black in the centre, more bloodred on the outer half, later, after picking, becoming more brownish.

Lamellae: L:88, l:0-1; adnate, subdistant; brittle; ever so slightly eroded to smooth lamellar margin; browning margins around the pileal margin with age; white.

Stipe: 42×11 mm; cilindrical, subclavate, slightly taperint to top or sometimes brodened at apex; dry surface, slightly rugulose over entire length; flushed pink from the base towards a greadually whiter apex.

Context: Firm, brittle, somewhat hollow in the lower half of the stipe, no bruising or discolourations; white.

Smell/Taste: Initially lacking to slight fishy smell, much stronger fishy odour when older; no outspoken flavor.

Chemical analysis: Brownish green with FeSO4, indicating the relation to the R. xerampelina-group, especially in combination with the fishy smell; no reaction to KOH 3%.

Microscopy:

- Spores: Broadly ellipsid to broadly ovoid, sometimes (sub)globose; lots of warts (+/- 2 micron), some ridges and few connectives, rarely partially reticulate.

- Measurements (1000x, oil-immersion, H2O, 1 sd=1,02 micron):

- 7,65 × 6,12 micron
- 8,16 × 6,12 micron
- 7,14 × 6,63 micron
- 8,16 × 6,63 micron
- 9,18 × 6,12 micron
- 7,14 × 6,12 micron
- 7,14 × 6,12 micron
- 8,67 × 7,65 micron
- 8,16 × 6,12 micron
- 10,20 × 7,14 micron

av. 8,16 × 6,477 micron
stats. (7,14) 8,16 (10,20) x (6,12) 6,48 (7,65) micron

Ecology: Growing scattered or in small groups of three to four, closely associated with Salix in a swamp forest.

Notes: Gills turn brown during drying with heatlamp, fishy odour also increases significantly.

results.notes:
Description:

Pileus: 12-25 × 5-9 mm; convex with flattened centre, later irregular with depressed to umbilicate centre and decurving margin; surface dry, very finely squamulose; margin even at first, later crenate; vermilion to scarlet red, outmost margin bright yellow, drying up sordid orange from centre outwards, loses yellow margin then; hygrophanous.

Lamellae: L: 28-32, l: 1-3; distant, broadly adnate and slightly decurrent, thick, broad, alternating ventricose; margin smooth; yellowish white to yellow orange; hygrophanous.

Stipe: 42-46 × 2-6 mm; central, at first cylindrical, later often compressed with central groove on both sides; often bent at foot; surface dry, shiny, bald, irregular, over the breadth lumpy; concolourous with pileus; basal mycelium white.

Context: Relatively brittle, firm in the cortex, somewhat watery/cottony in the centre, very thin in pileus; cortex of the stipe runs deep into the pileal margin; tad paler than the exterior; hygrophanous.

Smell/Taste: No distinct smell, tastes mild.

Microscopy: No microscopic analysis done

Ecology: Low yield grassland, moist sandy soil, between moss and plants, such as: Plantago lanceolata and Hypochaeris sp.; sharing habitat with Entoloma spec., Clavulinopsis spec. and Galerina spec.; scattered in small subgroups, forming larger troops.

results.notes:
Pileus: 45 × 13 mm; pulvinate, fine velutinouse, finely cracked pileipellis, in the cracks pink of colour; uniformly brown, pink context visible where damaged; equal margin; no discolouration after bruising.

Pores/Tubes: Large, irregular, greenish yellow with reddish brown smudges; tubes up to 9 mm long, decurrent across the apex; both not or very faintly bruising blue.

Stipe: 50 × 70 mm; eccentric, cylindrical, slightly bent; dry, very finely floccose-granulose; bright beet red, pale at apex, yellowish white basal mycelium, underneath the white layer the foot is yellow; none to very faint beet red after bruising.

Context: Soft in the pileus, firm in the stipe; bright golden yellow, paler in the pileus, deep beet red in the stipe, especially in the middle part, yellow again in the base; slow and faint bruising.

Smell/Taste: Sour-ish, yet fresh of scent, taste indistinct.

Microscopy: No microscopic analysis.

Ecology: Dry sandy soil with fairly thick layer of leaf litter and humus, associated with Quercus sp. and Fagus sp.

results.notes:
[OMS Fall Mycocamp]

Growing profusely on bark of a living spruce tree, just behind the Kramer Memorial (bench and plaque), Cape Falcon Trail. Caps were less than 1 cm wide, except one that was actually growing in duff (second photo) and was about 1.5 cm.

Cap pellicle was completely separable, and there was blue at the stem base, and only there.

This is an unusual find and it was a beautiful collection, dried the same day, but when I looked at it a weak later, it was almost totally destroyed by mold and I wasn’t able to see much under the scope. Fortunately, I could see enough spores (about 10) to be confident that they are subglobose, 7-8 × 6-6.5, exactly as in M. subcaerulea — a species known only from Eastern United States, growing on hardwood debris/bark/wood. Smith wrote: “Although I have watched for it along the Pacific Coast, I have never been able to find it there”.

Only the habitat and perhaps the small size are at odds with the description of M. subcaerulea.

Habitat:
On damp soil/compost heap mixed with decomposed straw and small shredded woody debris

Gills:
Free from stem, nearly distant, transition from white to grey to black

Stem:
around 3mm thick, yellowish-whitish, fragile and hollow, no ring remnant

Cap:
Umbrella shape, groved margins, fine brown hairs on the top of the cap, cap greyish in color, central dip with a dominant rusty brown coloration, around 50mm in diameter

Young caps orangish/brown with no universal veil

Spore print color:
Black

Other information:
No particular scent, temperatures varying from 21-24C, found in a valley
